Award.AwardTitle: Engineering Scholars Program: Increasing Access and Diversity (ESP Scholars)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The project is an engineering scholarship program (ESP Scholars) to increase the access and diversity in the engineering and engineering technology fields. It will provide scholarships to at least 75 talented and financially needy students with at least 50% from underrepresented groups (minorities and women). The project will increase the retention of ESP Scholars and enhance placement of graduating ESP students in the STEM workforce or enrollment in a four-year engineering degree program by improving student academic and support services. The scholarship program supports the development of student intellectual capacity. It incorporates best practices for retention of underrepresented students and provides continuing opportunities for students to build a cohort and explore common academic and social interests throughout their college experience. The project team will study similarities and differences between ESP students and non-ESP students. The broader impact of the project will be demonstrated by an increase in the number of students from underrepresented groups who major in engineering disciplines and receive associate degrees. Students will be supported by a diverse team of faculty, staff and industry representatives. The project will also demonstrate that stronger connections between two and four-year colleges will help diversify the pool of engineers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of the Engineering Scholars Program (ESP) at Anne Arundel Community College (AACC) was to increase the number of financially needy and intellectually talented students who complete AACC engineering programs, transfer to a four-year institution, and/or enter the workforce, with a particular focus on populations underrepresented in engineering.  (This was later broadened to include ALL STEM disciplines).   In order to accomplish these goals, AACC provided ESP scholars with enhanced student academic and support services including a week-long summer orientation, spring orientation, mentorship, access to industry professionals, student success workshops, field trips to industry and four-year institutions, job fairs, funding to attend professional conferences, and organized group study and tutoring.

Through these activities ESP scholars learned how to apply skills in their field of study that are useful throughout college and beyond, made connections between course content and industry, felt a stronger sense of community, increased confidence, and ultimately increased their potential for academic success.

Over the eight-year grant period, AACC provided $479,480 in scholarships to a total of 120 student scholars, exceeding the initial project goal of 75 students. On average, 51% of each annual cohort was composed of students from populations underrepresented in STEM disciplines, exceeding the project goal of 50%.  The average annual retention rate was 82%, far exceeding the college-wide retention rate of 63%. Of those participants who were eligible to graduate (i.e. had been enrolled for two years in a two-year program and continued to meet project eligibility criteria), 64% graduated and/or transferred to a four-year institution. While employment in a STEM field was a project goal, capturing post-graduation employment outcomes proved difficult after students left the college. Feedback from students while they were still enrolled indicated  that more than 1/3 of them had already secured a position in a STEM field. 

The Intellectual Merit of this project is intrinsic to the intent of the program which was to support the development of student intellectual capacity. By applying best practices for retention and continuing opportunities for students to build a cohort and explore common academic and social interests, the project increased the knowledge and success of the ESP scholars. Since faculty and student support staff received training in advising and mentoring, their capacity to provide meaningful support to the students was increased as well.

The Broader Impacts of this project include the increase in qualified workers in engineering and other STEM industries as well as the enhanced mentoring and advising skills among ESP faculty that will continue to support students beyond the life of this project. Furthermore, the dissemination activities conducted on behalf of this project, including presentations to high school guidance counselors, college students, faculty, staff and transition advisors, the college board of trustees, and the League for Innovation in Community Colleges, ensured that the outreach and student success strategies developed and implemented by this project were shared within the college community, the local school system, and the broader national community college network.
